# Completed Projects
## Paterson City Mayor's Office Collaboration

As part of a white paper published by Montclair State University, two of my peers and I worked in close collaboration with the Paterson City Mayor's Office to identify and develop solutions to an ongoing crisis in local emergency shelters. Local state law stipulates that the average length of stay in an emergency shelter must remain below a set number of days, but local shelters were not in compliance. We found that, by utilizing niche techniques ranging from merging Continuum of Cares to modifying funding schemes, local emergency shelter conditions could be brought into compliance with New Jersey state law.

# Planned Projects
## An Exploratory Study of End-of-Life Planning Among Unsheltered and Unhoused Individuals

This project aims to examine how unsheltered and unhoused individuals engage in end-of-life (EoL) planning, an area that remains largely overlooked in homelessness and public health research. By drawing on survey data and semi-structured interviews, the study will explore how shelter status, geographic mobility, and access to medical and legal resources shape attitudes toward and engagement with EoL planning. By distinguishing between unsheltered individuals and those who are unhoused but mobile (e.g., living in vehicles), the research aims to highlight how mobility and fragmented service systems can disrupt continuity of care and planning at lifeâ€™s end. It is my hope the findings will inform more humane and effective policies within Continuums of Care, emphasizing the importance of aligning end-of-life decisions with individual wishes rather than structural constraints.
